intro: Acer pectinatum, commonly known as the Japanese maple, is a deciduous tree native to the mountainous regions of Japan. It is characterized by its delicate, palmate leaves that turn vibrant shades of red and orange in autumn. The plant typically grows to a height of 6–12 meters, with a broad, rounded crown. Its flowers are small and inconspicuous, appearing in clusters before the leaves emerge in spring. The bark is smooth and grayish-brown, becoming fissured with age.
